speaker: Amit Varma
message: I had a strange dream the other night. I had been called to the PMO for dinner with the Prime Minister. Modiji was there, Jaitleyji was there, Hasmukhbhai was there. Modiji was at his hospitable best, starting me off with some cheese and white wine. He told me, We don't serve red wine. Ha ha ha ha ha. Anyway, once I was suitably lubricated, Modiji leaned forward and said, Amit, you are the economic commentator I respect most in this country. From day one of demonetization, you got it right. You wrote about what a disaster it was. For many years, you have been the wisest one. So now tell me, O great soul, O fountain of knowledge, what is the state of the economy like in India? I replied, Namo, bro, I gotta be honest with you. Things are a mess. Demon screwed the informal sector and small businesses. GST with all these slabs and exemptions, even worse. Red tape has gone up. Compliance is hard. A new Inspector Raj is being unleashed. Exporters are suffering. Small businesses are suffering. It's a mess. Then he said, This bloody economy. I have such great speech writers and social media trolls. And still the economy is not doing well. It baffles me. I need food. Jaitleyji rang a bell and an eminent economist wearing a waiter's uniform walked in. He said to Modiji, Kya lau sir? Whatever you want, I will bring it for you. Modiji whispered something in his ear. I couldn't quite make out what he said. And then he elaborated, And make sure it's medium rare. Hare Modiji, I said. What is it that you're eating? Modiji said, Amit, my boy. Why so serious? Don't be shocked. We all worship in our own way.

speaker: Unknown
message: Welcome to The Seen and The Unseen. Our weekly podcast on economics, politics and behavioral science. Please welcome your host, Amit Badma.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Welcome to The Seen and The Unseen. In today's episode, I want to do a roundup of the state of the Indian economy. Now, the economy is not doing very well. And many of the things wrong with it are the Unseen effects. Of demonetization and GST. Before I bring in my guest for today, I want to spend a little while talking about each of these. As Modiji mentioned in my dream, I have been writing against demon from day one in publications like The Times of India and The Hindu Business Line. The second episode of The Seen and The Unseen was on demonetization. My guest in that was Suyash Rai. You can check out the archives at seenunseen.in. Some people say that demon was a good idea that was implemented badly. This is nonsense. It was a terrible idea from the start. This is mainly because it was not an attack on high denomination notes to begin with. In 1978, when the last demonetization happened, the notes that were demonetized were only 0.6% of the notes in circulation. They were basically used to store money and not to actually spend it. By contrast, this time, 1000 rupee and 500 rupee notes constituted 86% of the money supply and are used by the common man and the rich. Used by the common man for daily transactions. Modiji may not have bought something from a store for a couple of decades and probably didn't know this sitting in his ivory tower. And from the insider accounts I have heard, he also didn't consult any of the eminent economists who worked with him. Anyway, so overnight there was a shortage of cash and hundreds of millions of people had to queue up for hours to get a hand on their own money. This was easily the largest assault on property rights in human history. The informal sector depends on cash and was crippled by this. Small businesses everywhere were hurt. And as expected, our GDP growth rate suffered as well. Demon was supposed to attack black money, but it was estimated at the time that only 6% of the black money was stored in the form of cash. And even that got neatly laundered. Basically, demonetization crippled our economy and achieved absolutely nothing. For more details on this too, listen to my February episode on this with Suresh Rai at cnunseen.in. I've done two episodes on GST, first with Devangshu Dutta and then with Vivek Kaul. My episode with Devangshu happened before GST was implemented. And Devangshu warned that if there were too many slabs and exemptions, it might defeat the whole purpose. Vivek did an episode with me after GST was implemented and the problems with it were exactly as Devangshu had feared. Too many slabs and exemptions that made it the opposite of a good and simple tax. Indeed, there were now so many regulations that compliance was hard and time-consuming and observers feared that a new Inspector Raj may well be on the way. Anyway, my guest on the show today is Vivek Kaul himself, a prolific author and columnist for Equity Master and, much to my good fortune, a frequent guest on The Seen and The Unseen. Vivek, welcome back to the show.

And when the government prints money, it's basically creating inflation, which is a tax on the poor. So, typically what used to happen was that when the Red Cross rations came, suddenly everybody had cigarettes and they used to start using those cigarettes to exchange, you know, for a cup of coffee or tea and so on and so forth. Now, because there was a sudden increase in the inflow of cigarettes, the prices of, you know, coffee and tea used to go up in the sense that, you know, earlier maybe two cigarettes for a coffee and, you know, after the inflow of cigarettes, it used to become three cigarettes for a coffee.

Now, John Maynard Keynes, you know, in 1936, in his magnum opus, The General Theory of Money, Interest and Employment, essentially suggested that when the economy is not doing well, when the private sector is not spending enough money, the government should cut tax rates. He also suggested that the governments should spend more money during that period than they, you know, than they spend in other periods. So, this is something that politicians and economists have latched on to since 1936 and every time an economy is in trouble anywhere in the world, this is the first suggestion that is given. Now, it needs to be explained here that, you know, when Keynes was making these suggestions, the governments did not run fiscal deficits. That is what used to happen back then was that their income was equal to their expenditure. So, Keynes' argument was that you essentially accumulate money when the going is good and then you spend it when the going is not so good. But what happened was people just ran with one part of the argument and, you know, the government should spend money when the going is not good. Anyway, so to get back to the point, now with the economy not doing well, obviously all these economists and, you know, some politicians also have been suggesting that the government should spend more money than it is actually spending.
